description: Borrowed from Latin dīrectus, perfect passive participle of dīrigō (“straighten, direct”), from dis- (“asunder, in pieces, apart, in two”) + regō (“make straight, rule”). Compare dress.  Doublet of derecho.

adjectives.description: direct (comparative more direct, superlative most direct)

entries.meaning: Straight; not crooked, oblique, or circuitous; leading by the short or shortest way to a point or end.
examples: the most direct route between two buildings
He nowhere, that I know, says it in direct words.

entries.meaning: In the line of descent; not collateral.
examples: a descendant in the direct line

entries.meaning: (astronomy) In the direction of the general planetary motion, or from west to east; in the order of the signs; not retrograde; said of the motion of a celestial body.
(political science) Pertaining to, or effected immediately by, action of the people through their votes instead of through one or more representatives or delegates.
(aviation, travel) having a single flight number.

adverbs.description: direct (comparative more direct, superlative most direct)

examples: Presumably Mary is to carry messages that she, Anne, is too delicate to convey direct.

verbs.description: direct (third-person singular simple present directs, present participle directing, simple past and past participle directed)

examples: to direct the affairs of a nation or the movements of an army
They directed their fire towards the men on the wall.
He directed his question to the room in general.

entries.meaning: To point out to or show (somebody) the right course or way; to guide, as by pointing out the way.
examples: He directed me to the left-hand road.

entries.meaning: To point out to with authority; to instruct as a superior; to order.
examples: She directed them to leave immediately.

entries.meaning: (dated) To address (a letter) to a particular person or place.
examples: [A]s I do not know where I shall be, and shall have my letters sent after me as soon as I do know, continue to direct hither.
